gobblin.source.extractor.extract.jdbc

Class JdbcExtractor

  • java.lang.Object
    • gobblin.source.extractor.extract.QueryBasedExtractor<com.google.gson.JsonArray,com.google.gson.JsonElement>
      • gobblin.source.extractor.extract.jdbc.JdbcExtractor
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    JdbcSpecificLayer, ProtocolSpecificLayer<com.google.gson.JsonArray,com.google.gson.JsonElement>, SourceSpecificLayer<com.google.gson.JsonArray,com.google.gson.JsonElement>, Extractor<com.google.gson.JsonArray,com.google.gson.JsonElement>, Closeable, AutoCloseable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    MysqlExtractor, OracleExtractor, SqlServerExtractor, TeradataExtractor

    public abstract class JdbcExtractor
extends QueryBasedExtractor<com.google.gson.JsonArray,com.google.gson.JsonElement>
implements SourceSpecificLayer<com.google.gson.JsonArray,com.google.gson.JsonElement>, JdbcSpecificLayer
    Extract data using JDBC protocol

      • convertBitToBoolean

        protected boolean convertBitToBoolean()
        HACK: there is a bug in the MysqlExtractor where tinyint columns are always treated as ints. There are MySQL jdbc driver setting (tinyInt1isBit=true and transformedBitIsBoolean=false) that can cause tinyint(1) columns to be treated as BIT/BOOLEAN columns. The default behavior is to treat tinyint(1) as BIT. Currently, MysqlExtractor.getDataTypeMap() uses the information_schema to check types. That does not do the above conversion. parseColumnAsString(ResultSet, ResultSetMetaData, int) which does the above type mapping. On the other hand, SqlServerExtractor treats BIT columns as Booleans. So we can be in a bind where sometimes BIT has to be converted to an int (for backwards compatibility in MySQL) and sometimes to a Boolean (for SqlServer). This function adds configurable behavior depending on the Extractor type.
